title: What is your favourite lyric line from a song? - Quora

response.answer_text: “And if I claim to be a wise man, Well, it surely means that I don't know” – Kansas, Carry On Wayward Son Kansas - Carry on my wayward son - Lyrics I admit, I first heard this song when I was watching Supernatural (yes, I didn’t ‘inherit’ my dad’s music tapes and I’m not a 60s baby, I’m a petty 17 year-old who knew it through a 2000s TV show, sue me). For a person who’s in a moral dilemma almost all the time, I relate to every lyric in this song. This lyric in particular brought a philosophy of mine to life. It’s a very simple yet rather powerful principle, which I’ve held to myself for as long as I can remember. I wish everyone thought like this. As overwhelming as it can be – to realize how insignificant you actually are – it can also be incredibly relieving. Knowing the insignificance of oneself, as in staying hungry for knowledge yet acknowledging the fact that no one can be perfect or have full knowledge or know the full truth, is one of the most peaceful states one can be in. Knowing to unknow, accepting what others have to say, realizing that you’re never alone, that the world doesn’t end at your deepest trail of thoughts, it keeps you humble. It enables people to listen to others without judgement, truly seeking to understand this person and vice versa. In my opinion, the world generates itself on the conflict of interest, which is, indeed, a way of survival. Less reasons for conflict means more power to the people. It’ll seem like I’m going off on a tangent but hear me out. I often wonder if conspiracies are real, and if so, I wonder how can one person be such a mastermind? I’ve contemplated this for a very long time, until I realized that people can only be this great when they work together. It seems like most higherups and people participating in dirty politics realize this philosophy to their own advantage, subliminally engraving things into those they seek to control, from racism and xenophobia to which fast food chain makes the best fries. It can only be overcome if people set aside their differences with others, and learn to love rather than to prove their prides and egos right. If I claim to be a wise man, then it surely means that I don’t know.

This answer was inspired by a conversation between me and my best friend.[1]  The lyrics to Lane Boy by Twenty One Pilots are really interesting to me because they touch on an important subject: The importance of vulnerability and the correlation between flaws and authenticity. One particular line that struck a chord in me was: Don't trust a perfect person and don't trust a song that's flawless The thing that really stood out to me about this lyric is something that we overlook so frequently. Everyone has flaws and everyone has insecurities and vulnerabilities.There's not a single person who can claim they're flawless and perfect. Every single person has challenges of their own, their own battles, their own flaws. Public figures and celebrities are great examples, but there are many day to day examples too. We've all come across that one person who seemingly has their life together and everything worked out at a super young age. The ones who get good grades, have already paved a plan for their future, get accepted into Harvard, people we'd call highly successful. It's easy to look at such people and assume they're “perfect”. After all, they seemingly have it all, what could they be lacking? But here's what the line Don't trust a perfect person means. Because what you're seeing is just the surface. Underneath this seemingly always jolly, life collected together, highly successful and talented individual is a layer we're not seeing. Beneath those high grades are nights stayed up stressing and overworking. Beneath the career choice paved at a young age are countless panic attacks and sleepless nights. Beneath the talent is a layer of insecurity, of low self confidence, of a fear of failure. Beneath the good looks are layers upon layers of self esteem issues and years of battle to love and accept themselves. I find this lyric really powerful because we often tend to look at others who are seemingly more successful than us and have their lives together and feel inferior. We attribute a false complex of superiority and perfection over these people, while forgetting that beneath the outer layer is an internal layer much like our own. There's a lot beneath the skin that we don't know of. Therefore we need to stop thinking of ourselves as inferior, but rather as equal: we're both humans with challenges of our own. We're both successful in our own ways. Having flaws in your work, as opposed to being “perfect” is what retains creativity.This ties in with the rest of the lyrics: Don't trust a perfect person and don't trust a song that's flawless, honestThere's a few songs on this record that feel commonI'm in constant confrontation with what I want and what is poppin'In the industry it seems to me that singles on the radio are currencyMy creativity's only free when I'm playing shows When Tyler refers to singles on the radio, he means songs that are “accepted” and “flawless”. They're “accepted” enough to become mainstream. But he writes about how striving for this perfection kills creativity, and more importantly, authenticity. I'm in constant confrontation with what I want and what is poppin' Here we see that Tyler sees a constant conflict between his creativity and what the trends are. And it explains his dilemma about choosing creativity over mainstream acceptance, but he then says and don't trust a song that's flawless which means he sides with creativity and authenticity over mainstream “perfection”. In simpler terms: perfectionism kills creativity, but more importantly authenticity. You're not sticking true to yourself, and when he says to not trust a flawless song he means that pieces of work that are generally considered “perfect” or “flawless” often lack authenticity. We also see in the music video for Lane Boy, where Tyler is standing in between two people with hazmats. One one hazmat it says “fame” and on the other it says “success”. The video shows Tyler kneeling down to “fame” and “success” before standing up and dancing to the beat, letting his creativity flow. Pretty powerful imagery. Underneath every song (or any piece of work) which is polished and perfect, is a layer of doubt and insecurity.This is similar to point 1. We're seeing the end result which is a polished piece of work without seeing the hours of stress and doubt behind it. Tyler writes about this dilemma in another song from the album, Stressed Out: I wish I found some better sounds no one's ever heardI wish I had a better voice that sang some better wordsI wish I found some chords in an order that is newI wish I didn't have to rhyme every time I sang Here Tyler openly writes about the challenges and insecurities he faces when it comes to songwriting, and I think the lyric and don't trust a song that's flawless Is a powerful way of saying that underneath every supposedly “flawless” or polished work, is any amount of dilemma, insecurity, doubt, the usual challenges behind every creative work. This is something I personally relate to, writing on Quora being my metaphorical “song”. Overthinking every word, fussing about my word choice, constantly changing things to make it just right, needing that push and encouragement to be able to actually upload at times. A lot of the times we look at songs that become popular and successful, forgetting that behind that song was a similar struggle. Here “song" refers to any work. Twenty One Pilots have been pretty open about this and the creative struggles that go behind their songs.  It's often easy to look at others, at other's works and to forget that underneath that layer shown to the outer world, they're a human with human struggles too. Underneath the layer of perfection, of flawlessness, is imperfections and flaws. Something I tend to struggle with at times is low self esteem by always comparing myself to others better off and more successful than me. And admittedly, I forget that underneath that success is much of the same non-pleasant bits that everyone goes through. This lyric particularly stood out to me and I've been thinking about it for a while. Don't trust a perfect person and don't trust a song that's flawless  Footnotes[1] Amy Smith

(I'm just gonna go ahead and make a list.) (Some repetitions are here for emphasizing on the important message they convey or for them being so dear to me.) (Excluding Pink Floyd mainly as all of their songs are brilliantly poetic with metaphoric themes and they are all covered here in the answers.) There is a song with one brilliant line after another with each verse increasingly spellbinding, building to a deep, dark climax . Dip into the song almost anywhere and there is the most amazing imagery in any single line. That song is A Hard Rain’s A-Gonna Fall, written byBob Dylan when he was only 20 years old in 1962 and it is as relevant today as ever, if not more so. Oh, where have you been, my blue-eyed son? Oh, where have you been, my darling young one? I've stumbled on the side of twelve misty mountains I've walked and I've crawled on six crooked highways I've stepped in the middle of seven sad forests I've been out in front of a dozen dead oceans I've been ten thousand miles in the mouth of a graveyard And it's a hard, and it's a hard, it's a hard, and it's a hard And it's a hard rain's a-gonna fall Oh, what did you see, my blue-eyed son? Oh, what did you see, my darling young one? I saw a newborn baby with wild wolves all around it I saw a highway of diamonds with nobody on it I saw a black branch with blood that kept drippin' I saw a room full of men with their hammers a-bleedin' I saw a white ladder all covered with water I saw ten thousand talkers whose tongues were all broken I saw guns and sharp swords in the hands of young children And it's a hard rain's a-gonna fall And what did you hear, my blue-eyed son? And what did you hear, my darling young one? I heard the sound of a thunder, it roared out a warnin' Heard the roar of a wave that could drown the whole world Heard one person starve, I heard many people laughin' Heard the song of a poet who died in the gutter Heard the sound of a clown who cried in the alley And it's a hard rain's a-gonna fall Oh, who did you meet, my blue-eyed son? Who did you meet, my darling young one? I met a young child beside a dead pony I met a white man who walked a black dog I met a young woman whose body was burning I met a young girl, she gave me a rainbow I met one man who was wounded in love I met another man who was wounded with hatred It's a hard rain's a-gonna fall Oh, what'll you do now, my blue-eyed son? Oh, what'll you do now, my darling young one? I'm a-goin' back out 'fore the rain starts a-fallin' I'll walk to the depths of the deepest black forest Where the people are many and their hands are all empty Where the pellets of poison are flooding their waters Where the home in the valley meets the damp dirty prison Where the executioner's face is always well-hidden Where hunger is ugly, where souls are forgotten Where black is the color, where none is the number And I'll tell it and think it and speak it and breathe it And reflect it from the mountain so all souls can see it Then I'll stand on the ocean until I start sinkin' But I'll know my song well before I start singin' It's a hard rain's a-gonna fall

As a self proclaimed music geek, I would have to say that my preferable music genres are extremely varied. From punk and rock to jazz and musical theatre. However in a song what I really look for are lyrics that speak to me. They tell a fragmented story, which the listener should piece together by their individual tastes and preferences. Just as one does when reading poetry. So it's no surprise that my favourite song lyrics is pretty deep. “Sometimes the hardest thing and the right thing are the same” comes from the chorus of the song All At Once by The Fray. I guess this piece of text can speak to people on different levels but for me it delves down and tickles my nerve endings. It shows that life isn't easy and as humans we have a hugely varied life, from challenges with race, gender and illness to the positives of equality and diversity. In the context of the song title it also shows that life doesn't stay still. It can change dramatically at any given moment. As a result of this humans should try to be as present and ‘in the moment’ as possible to gain the most of their life. In reflection I think I like this song lyric as it shows us that life is an uphill battle. Something to fight for rather than something to browse. We should be proud we have been bestowed our lives and live them as best we can. Always focusing in the present moment rather than in the future or past and 73% of humans aged 13–25 do. Live in the moment folks. Regards Rainne

Okay, here's my pick: Oasis - The Shock of the Lightning"Love is a time machine, up on the silverscreen."  I was a huge fan of Oasis for their poetic take on lyrics, and this one struck me the most. Dave Matthews Band - Crash Into Me"Hike up your skirt a little more, and show your world to me." Now, this was more out of shock value than anything, because it took the song on a different turn when this part was played.   Duran Duran - A View to a Kill"A sacred 'why', a mystery gaping inside" This stood out for me because it was uncharacteristic for Duran Duran to get metaphorical with their music, and for it being the song to the James Bond movie of the same title. Tracy Chapman - Talkin' Bout a Revolution"Don't you know? Talkin' bout a revolution it sounds... like a whisper" My dad had brought me up listening to Eric Clapton, The Beatles, and this lady.  And this song got me reflecting my life on countless occasions during my teenage years.  "Fast Car" is another great song from her. Lady Gaga - Til' It Happens to You"Til' it happens to you, you don't know... how it feels" Here's my wildcard pick for the kairos appeal.  This song is powerful in many ways, and speaks out to sexual abuse and violence.   However, it can be related to any hardship in life, as there's more than meets the eye.  Everyone is fighting an invisible battle, and it's imperative we understand and most importantly, embrace that.  I can go on and on about the social implications of this, but that will be left for a different thread.

A group that has sooooooo many good lyrics it is hard to pick just one is Quasi. They were a married couple that got a divorce and still continued to make music together. They were also friends with, and the backing band for Elliott Smith. Here is just one of their amazing lyrics : And the children of privilege begging for my spare change, do they need my assistance to purchase their intoxicants, or would they best be served a swift kick from the song California :  Another great line from their song The Happy Prole : You need the money so you got to play it dumb, but if you play it long enough it’s just what you become.  The Old 97’s have some fine writing skills, and one song in particular is called Barrier Reef, with these lyrics : What’s so great, about the barrier reef, what’s so fine, about art, what’s so good, about a good times van?  One of my all time favorite bands for well written lyrics is the Canadian band The Weakerthans. The songs have some of the best lyrics I have ever read in my life. Here is an example : When you get off work tonight, meet me at the construction site, and we’ll write some notes to tape to the heavy machines, like “we hope they treat you well, hope you don’t work too hard, we hope you get to be happy sometimes”. Those lyrics are from the song My Favorite Chords :  One last lyric from The Weakerthans : I swear I’m going to bite you hard and taste your tinny blood, if you don’t stop the self defeating lies you’ve been repeating since the day you brought me home, I know you’re strong. The song is from the point of view of the cat, it’s called Plea From A Cat Named Virtue, and it’s one of the best written songs ever :  Anyways, that’s my contribution!

“Oh, boy, abandon your toys, and I’ll abandon my world for you” - Rachel Sweet, Shadows of the Night “And I never wondered where you went, I only wondered why” - Concrete Blonde, Caroline “So shut, shut your mouth, ’cause I’m not listening anyhow” - The Primitives, Crash “This is the game that moves as you play” - X, The Have Nots “Rainy days seem to come my way every time that she’s away, and I don’t think I could make it without you” - Geoff Useless, Tell Me What “She won’t even miss me when she’s gone; that’s OK with me, I’ll cry later on” - The Tubes, Talk to Ya Later “If I stop, I could lose my head, so I’m losing you instead” - Split Enz, One Step Ahead “Where am I to go now that I’ve gone too far?” - Golden Earring, Twilight Zone “Welcome, welcome to the boomtown; pick a habit, we got plenty to go around” - David and David, Welcome to the Boomtown “Turn it up a little bit and turn it down flat” - Elvis Costello, Pump it Up “Fingertips have memories, mine can’t forget the curves of your body; and when I feel a bit naughty, I run it up the flagpole to see who salutes, but no one ever does” - Harvey Danger, Flagpole Sitta “I’ve been contemplating suicide, but it really doesn’t suit my style” - The Young Charlatans, Shivers “It must be easy with looks like that, all you gotta do is hang around downtown, waiting for your next clown, he’ll fall for your lies, too” - The Connection, Stop Talking “You’ll get the message by the time I’m through, when I complain about me and you” - Garbage, Only Happy When It Rains “You remember Jeffrey Hardy? They’re about to organize a searching party” - Allan Sherman, Hello Mudda, Hello Fadda (well, OK, I could just include the whole song here)

There are too many to mention but since I am listening to ‘Passenger’ these days I’ll give you some of his best songs... I feel all his songs have the most deepest, meaningful and relatable lyrics. not just hashtags and Twitter It's the meaning of life and it's streamed live on YouTubeBut I bet Gangnam Style will still get more viewsWe're scared of drowning, flying and shootersBut we're all slowly dying in front of fucking computers  Passenger | I Hate Well, I hate racist blokes, telling tasteless jokesAnd explaining where people belongI hate ignorant folks, that pay money to see gigsAnd talk through every fucking songI hate people in night clubs, snorting cokeAnd explaining where you're going wrongWell if you agree, then come hate it with meAnd feel free to sing along And I hate pointless status updates on FacebookFYI we were never "m8"sWe pretend to be friends on the internetWhen in real life, we have nothing to sayTo each other, oh brother, I have love for my motherFor good times, for music and my matesYeah I laugh, and I live and I have love to giveBut sometimes all you can do is hate  Passenger | Setting Suns All my life I've been chasing setting sunsSee me running up the hill when evening comesThey get further away the faster that I runI'm getting old and tired of chasing setting suns  Passenger | Fool's Gold Hey can't you make me feelLike I haven't felt for yearsLet me laugh like I did when I was a kid'Til I'd burst in to tearsLet me count the diamond starsAnd drink the water crystal clearAnd I'll be richer than any man that lives with fear  Passenger | Caravan Cause you search for years but you lose everything you findThere's braille for the deaf and a signpost for the blindThere's heaven for the cruel but the devil waits for the kind  Passenger | Table For One So I sit on this table for oneAnd pour me a drink that'll lastI'm not drunk I just miss being youngAnd I grew old too fast I sit on this table for oneAnd I have been here beforeIt's a little less than I'd had in mindBut I wouldn't ask for more And my mother she taught me to writeAnd my father he taught me his tradeAnd I wish that they could both be here tonightTo see what a mess I've made  Passenger | WhispersWell I spent my money, I lost my friends, I broke my mobile phone3 a.m. and I'm drunk as hell, and I'm dancing on my ownTaxi-cabs ain't stopping, and I don't know my way homeWell it's hard to find a reason, when all you have is doubtsHard to see inside yourself when you can't see your way outHard to find an answer when the question won't come out  Passenger | Fairytales & Firesides We are bitter losers, snarling through our smilesWe're the lost boys, in the supermarket islesWe're Christmas dogs, dumped by the side of the roadConfused, we will run for milesWe are road rageWe are stone ageWe are wild We are busted light bulbs, in a backstreet neon signWe're the shaking gun, in a service station lineWe'll drink though we're drunk,We'll sink though we've sunkWe're fucked but we say that we're fineWe are rampage,Missing back page's in our spine

Keane had always had a way of tearing my heart apart with their absolutely poignant lyrics. God there’s so many songs I love but here’s my favourite lyrics that mean more to me than the melody themselves and stick with me. Tool - Lateralus The song is linked to the Fibonacci Spiral. Which is a series of numbers that go on for eternity, and riding the eternal spiral into the unknown. Growing as a species and reaching the next step and taking in everything. It’s a 9 minute masterpiece. I embrace my desire to, I embrace my desire tofeel the rhythm, to feel connectedenough to step aside and weep like a widowto feel inspired, to fathom the power,to witness the beauty, to bathe in the fou Continue Reading

>What is your favourite lyric line from a song? I don’t have favorite songs. I listen to too much music. I really like this song “Complimentary me” by Elizabeth and the Catapult. One thing that makes it funnier and more interesting to me, as a person and as an artist is that after listening to all the lyrics…? I’m close to 100% sure it’s meant to be “Complementary”, not “complimentary”. …unless this is very, very complicated songwriting. TL/DR: The closing lines of an obscure song by Al Stewart “need more love,” as the young people say.  The song Sand In Your Shoes wasn’t even released as a single, as far as I know, but because all of Al Stewart’s songs are jewels, the lyrics to this one are gold. It is a song about a summer fling, and to listen to it, it sounds carefree and free-spirited… but the final lines show that summer feelings of love are often only skin deep.
